text:
Hey, everyone. This is Alex from engVid;
and today, I want to talk to you about

how to tell if you are an
intermediate-English learner. So, these

are going to be some guidelines to let
you know if you are making progress, and

if you are above the beginner level, and
if you're maybe ready to start looking

at advanced-student content. So, the
first thing you should be able to do if

you are an intermediate-English student
is to be able to talk about your daily

routines, your likes, your dislikes,
your personal preferences. So, for

example, if I ask you: "What do you do
every day?" you can tell me: "I get up

at seven am. I have breakfast. I brush
my teeth." You probably get dressed

before that. "I go to work. I have
lunch. I come home, and then I relax

before I go to sleep" — something like
this. And you're able to answer

questions, like: "What do you like to do
in your free time? What hobbies do you

have?" And you can say: "Well, I like to
do this. I don't like to do that. I

prefer this instead of that". So, you're
able to talk about your daily routines,

your likes, your dislikes, and your
preferences. Number two: You should be

very comfortable with the English
alphabet, if you want to consider

yourself an intermediate-level student.
So, you can spell things out — if people

ask you to spell your name, for example.
Numbers are another area that you should

be able to be comfortable with at this
stage. So, if someone asks you for your

phone number, for example, you can say
it in English without needing to, you

know... translate in your mind. Now,
before I continue, I want to state that,

you know... this list, there are going
to be some things that even advanced

students have trouble with. You will
always have blind spots. "Blind spots"

are, you know... areas that are a
problem that maybe you haven't

considered, or you haven't worked on
enough just yet.

Next: You can express what you want in
public places. So, whether you go to a

restaurant, whether you are at the
subway station, or another place where

you have to interact with someone and
ask for something — for example, if

you're a customer at a store; or a
client at a bank — you can express what

you need to do. So, you can use phrases,
like: "I would like", or: "I want", or:

"Can I have", or: "Could you help me
with...?". So, you're okay, basically,

making requests. Next: You are also
comfortable and familiar with a lot of

the basic elementary grammar topics. So,
in terms of tenses, if you are an

intermediate student, you should have
relative familiarity and comfort with

the present simple, the present
continuous, so: "I play", "I am

playing"; the simple past: "I played";
the present perfect: "I have played";

and the future simple: "I will play".
So, if you have at least a functional

use of these tenses; in addition to, of
course, knowing how to use things, like:

"much" and "many", having a basic
understanding of how articles work as

well, and how to use, you know...
adjectives beyond just: "cold" and

"hot", and colours, and things like
this. You should have a pretty good

command of these things. And you should
be able to, you know... make questions

with all of them. So: "What did you do
yesterday? Where did you go? Have you

seen that movie?" So, you're able to
have conversations with these tenses
with these grammar elements.

Now, in terms of comprehension and
listening skills, you should be able to

understand most basic children's
television shows and some movies. Of

course, this will depend on the movie,
this will depend on the show, as there

are still shows and movies where
characters speak a little quickly, for

example. But a show, like: "Peppa Pig",
for example — an intermediate student

should be able to understand what is
going on in an episode of "Peppa Pig"

because, number one: The pictures are
very clear and they tell you what's

happening. But number two: The language
is relatively simple, and they pause

quite frequently, and they speak at,
like, a good pace. So, an intermediate

student should be able to understand
what's happening in the majority of an

episode of "Peppa Pig", for example.
Finally, speaking takes time, but you're

able to do it. You're not ready to have
political discussions, for example, but

you can express yourself; you can
participate in a conversation with

people whose first language is English.
And you don't feel... well, you still

feel and you will feel for a while this
kind of, you know... sometimes anxious

feeling when you are speaking, like,
you're struggling to find the vocabulary

and the words that you need, but you can
express yourself.

So, if you go down the list of what I
just mentioned about, you know... your

routines, your likes, your dislikes,
being able to understand shows, knowing

the alphabet — these are all good ways
to let you know that: "You know what? I

am functional in English. I am an
intermediate student. People can

understand me now, and I can express
myself better." You should feel really

proud of yourself, honestly. And go back
and rewatch this video. Go over the

points again. Remind yourself of the
grammar topics that I mentioned — the

tenses, in particular, that you should
be comfortable with. And with some

practice, some dedicated practice daily,
regularly — you will get there; you will

make it happen. And if you enjoyed this
video, make sure to do the quiz. When

you're finished, subscribe to my channel
on YouTube, turn on notifications, give

me a thumbs up, and tell your friends.
Share with everyone, and leave a comment

down below. What level do you think you
are in your English journey right now?

And what do you think you need to do to
get to the next level? I'm genuinely

curious, so please let me know in the
comments. Until next time, I wish you

success in your studies. Thanks for
clicking.
